eu_initiatives:
The purpose of the UEMS Section of Psychiatry is to promote the highest standard of care for people who are affected by mental health problems in Europe through postgraduate training and continuing medical education of psychiatrists. 
The Section will achieve this by encouraging excellence in psychiatric education and training, from the undergraduate phase through to continuing professional development. 
The Section conducts its work by: 
•    Contributing to the harmonisation of professional standards in Europe 
•    Setting standards for education and learning across all stages of professional development in Europe 
•    Producing evidence based guidance on training and service related matters and 
•    Offering to Monitoring these standards 
 
The quality and harmonization of  
- undergraduate and postgraduate training in psychiatry 
- continuous medical education and professional development 
- standards of psychiatric care delivery and practice organisation 
 
Relevant topics: ethics and deontology in psychiatry, issues related to conflict of interest, legal aspects of professional qualifications in the field of psychiatry and psychotherapy, European professional card, revision of Directive 2005/36/EC (amended by Directive 2013/55/EU), primary, secondary and tertiary prevention of mental disorders, illegal drug use, pharmacovigilance, working time directive, public mental health, mental health for immigrants and refugees, empowerment of patients, mental health for carers and families of patients suffering from mental disorders, fighting stigma towards, and defending/promoting civil rights for psychiatric patients, E-health, telepsychiatry, developing transition psychiatry competencies

goals__remit:
With a current membership from most EU countries, UEMS Section of Psychiatry is representing national professional and scientific associations of medical specialists in psychiatry within the European Union and its associated countries. Next some other countries send observers to our semi-annual meetings.  
The Section is a part of a cupula association, the Union Européenne de Médecins Spécialistes based in Brussels. The Bureau comprising the President, a Vice-president for Training, a Vice-president for Continuous Medical Education, the Honorary Secretary, a Treasurer, and two other officers are responsible for the routine functioning of the organisation. 
The Section maintains working relations with the European Psychiatric Association, the European Federation for Psychiatric Trainees, the European Junior Doctors, the World Psychiatric Association and WHO.  
The Section produces documents on the website setting standards for high quality training and practice transmitted to the EU member states’ relevant authorities to encourage them to implement these recommendations.
